title: "We just can't find a way to tell stories with this whole League thing in the way." Well, WE did.
body:
http://i.imgur.com/tRZz0Hq.jpg

**[Factions](http://LeagueFactions.net)** is a community game mode and lore initiative based on faction versus faction matches, such as Noxus versus Ionia. We take the results of these matches, which anyone can start anytime, and use them to determine where the story goes next.

Today, Riot declared that it was simply not possible for them to write stories with the League and Summoners in the way.

With all due respect, I must question the sincerity of their efforts to do so before giving up, because a bunch of random players did it in their free time.

Take a look: **[The Lore of Factions](http://leaguefactions.net/2014/09/05/factions-lore/)**

Needless to say, given that Factions is all about the League and Summoners, we're not super happy about Riot's decision here. We'll deal.  But seriously, what gives?

They say that they can't have a war or other conflict because of the League. I guess they just couldn't come up with a workaround. Meanwhile, over at Factions, it seemed pretty obvious to us: the League's mission is to prevent apocalypse, not ensure world peace. They don't ban all war, they just insist that the states involved do not escalate the conflict to world-explodey levels, and eventually they step in and say "enough is enough" before enforcing a treaty.

They also said that it was just too hard explaining why Champions would join the League. Okay. Jinx? You really have a hard time understanding [why *Jinx* would want to join something that involved blowing things up all day and getting paid for it?](http://leaguefactions.net/hextech-revolution-update-5-get-jinxed/)

**EDIT:** As for **Summoners**, I'd like to add something further. I agree that omnipotent mind-controlling slavemasters are a creepy concept. That's not how I view Summoners, and it's not how they are in Factions. In Factions, Summoners are there to use their magic to help Champions out, while giving tactical advice and watching out for incoming attacks. I'm entertained by the idea of Summoners and Champions yelling at each other in the halls from time to time about "how could you miss that gank!?" or "you're the one who can't hit Alistar from 20 feet away, Mr. It's All Skill!" I think it's really important to give players a place in the story.

I'd like to hear Riot honestly try to make the case that it was just impossible to tell good stories with a setting that still left the game itself making some kind of in-universe sense.

Somebody once suggested that every department at Riot Games suffers from terrible management.  I didn't want to believe it at the time, but every day that goes by convinces me that it is true.

Bad decision-making.  A list of half-finished initiatives a mile long, enormously high priority put on things that don't really matter, while fundamental issues go unaddressed forever.

I remember working at a small start-up populated entirely by college grads that always thought their ideas were the pinnacle of brilliance, couldn't stay focused on the project as soon as it got hard, and threw temper tantrums if everybody else didn't do it "their way".  You can probably guess that company failed miserably.

Unfortunately that is exactly what Riot Games looks like from the outside.  They sure aren't failing yet, but moves like this lore reset sure doesn't build confidence as a brand.

Post: **[Riot’s Lore Retcon and Factions](http://leaguefactions.net/2014/09/04/riots-lore-retcon-and-factions/)**

Maybe we'll have to retcon Factions into a more abstract version that uses matches as symbolic representations of battles or something. We can deal. I just don't understand why Riot was so convinced it couldn't write lore without deleting the League from League.

> Maybe we'll have to retcon Factions into a more abstract version that uses matches as symbolic representations of battles or something.

This is waaaaaay more interesting than solving every fight by hiking out to the Land Where Nothing Matters and duking it out for half an hour. In the wake of the new lore changes, "Let's settle this on the Fields of Justice!" just sounds like "Let's settle this with a children's card game!" to me. 

The League just doesn't work unless champions have no relationship to each other whatsoever or are all backstabbing scumbags willing to betray their friends in order to... *what*, exactly? For fame? For power? For the Freljord? The League has always been a flimsy story construct.

The idea that there's an entire world behind League of Legends is laughable when any and all conflicts that ever happen are fought in *one* unchanging field where no one dies. 

If the League is to be considered a serious political entity, you have to submit to one of these hilarious truths:

* That everyone is okay with having geopolitical struggles solved by meaningless battle in a field by people who are thrown together at complete random to fight, regardless of their actual affiliations with one another or their "opponents"

OR

* That the fights are done for entertainment only, and the notoriety gained by arena warfare is enough to hold sway in actual politics the world over. 

Neither of these are practical, sensible, or believable. If Riot wants to move forward, and they want to do so by axing the idea of there being a League, I say more power to them. Only time will tell, however, if they do anything meaningful with their newfound freedom. As much as I'd love to read a novel following Ashe's exploits in attempting to unite the disparate clans of the Freljord, I have sincere doubts that we'll get anything remotely close. 

All in all, while I approve of the shift in lore direction, I don't think this means any change whatsoever in how lore is created or distributed. It's very likely to be more of the same for the foreseeable future.

Factions gets around that problem by restricting champion lists based on what faction you play for.  A match between Demacia and Noxus will be almost entirely composed of Demacian champions versus Noxian champions.

And really, you have to admit a lore/game relation of "The game is very similar to what happens in lore" is preferable to "The game has zero relation to what happens in lore".  90%+ of matches being non-cannon is better than 100% of matches being non-cannon.

At that point, though, it's still silly. You're telling two world superpowers that they can't go to war, but instead they get to play football to decide who would win if they actually COULD go to war.

It's more like: the two world superpowers realize that if either of them actually goes all-out it will escalate into another Rune War and destroy the planet, so they play football instead. World-destroying warfare is a pretty unpleasant contemplation for even a Noxian.

And again, there's still conflict, at least in the Factions version of the universe (which did not take 30 full-time writers to create) — but the League sets the boundaries, e.g., "no fighting beyond the island of Shon-Xan and its surrounding waters" or "neither side gets to deploy any more troops for the time being" or "instead of fighting a battle over this ancient city that will destroy said city with collateral damage, we'll hold a tournament and the winner will get to 'peacefully' take control of it."
You ever heard of the Cold War?  They may not have nukes, but they have nuclear-level magic.

There is plenty of actual conflict in the Factions universe. Look at **[Shon-Xan](http://leaguefactions.net/shon-xan/)**, for example. The League is not omnipotent, and knows that its legitimacy would quickly deteriorate if it invoked its power too frequently. ("The Council has made their decision—now let them enforce it!") It's just trying to set some limits to prevent warfare from destroying the planet.

Factions don't always respect the League, in Factions (e.g. when Demacia violated a League peace edict by marching on Zaun's mines in Shurima) or in regular LoL lore (where Demacia and Noxus fought over Kalamanda). So far, the League has been able to keep these outbursts somewhat in check, but only because the factions are ultimately in agreement about the risk of mutually assured destruction.

Why do the powerful factions continue supporting the League? There are really two components.

**Warfare**  
When it comes to the "big" issues, like the invasion of Shon-Xan, the major factions recognize that the League is a necessary arbiter to prevent another Rune War. It's not that different from the Cold War: yes, they'll skirmish, and fight proxy battles, but at the end of the day they'll keep their nukes in their silos and agree to be bound by a diplomatic regime they created because they realize, as Joshua would say, THE ONLY WINNING MOVE IS NOT TO PLAY.

**Smaller disputes**  
Most of what the League handles is not massive wars, but smaller arguments. A Bilgewater ship runs aground in the Isles, and Karthus wants to make them permanent residents, so there's a fight in the League for the fate of the crew. Piltover is taxing cupcakes from Bandle City at a higher rate because they argue the freshness charm on them makes them "magical artifacts"; Bandle City's yordlawyers disagree, so a round of what we call "solo queue matches" resolves the matter. This is simply an issue of efficiency: submitting to international arbitration resolves these disputes without lots of messy conflict. This happens IRL all the time with international corporations and states.

You say it's an issue of efficiency, but there's no way that arena warfare is the most efficient way to settle cupcake disputes. And again, you run into the issue of "What's more interesting," Karthus *declaring* that he wants to kill a bunch of pirates, so they all get sucked into the Fields of Justice to fight, or that there's an *actual naval battle* between the pirate crew and the ghost crew of an ancient sunken pirate ship? 

The League is a black hole into which anything interesting disappears. You said it yourself; every battle, no matter how large or small, is dictated by gladiatorial combat. 

Runeterra is a huge world filled with so many interesting characters and personalities--hell, we can even get story-important characters that *aren't* Champions now! Imagine reading about the personalities of the clan leaders of the Freljord, as told by Ashe from actual battle experience. Imagine reading how Ashe reacts to war coming to her own village, rather than everything being arbitrated by League fights. 

Riot figured out that they could tell an actual story using the world as a *setting* instead of a *backdrop* and I am so enthused that they want to do that.
I just wish they didn't have to completely tear down all the established stories and setting that we already had - and loved - in order to do that.

The major problem that a lot of people seem to have is this idea that canon battles in the League have to be RANDOM champions all thrown together for the Institute's purposes.  That's not how it works, and to state it that way means you don't know jack about the prior lore and shouldn't be waxing idiotic about it.  Was Ionia v. Noxus RANDOM CHAMPIONS?  The reason the League existed was because the Rune Wars nearly destroyed all of Runeterra.  So yes, most people would agree that a more controlled form of warfare was necessary.

I absolutely loved the challenges presented by the League as a framing device. I am sorely disappointed that projects like these are going to fall firmly into "non-canon" territory simply because the lore team took the easy way out.

Had to log in to upvote this. Honestly, it sounds like the Lore team just gave up trying to fit the story with the game, and it disappoints me to hear that. I'm sure there's a ton of reasons as to why they did it, but this is a video game. In order to tell the story best in a video game, you have to use the strengths from the media, instead of divorcing it completely from how the majority of players will experience the story.

What really bothers me is that since the game and story are separate, those special interactions between champs have little meaning, and all of our actions as summoners have no meaning at all. The champs themselves will feel like toys when I play them, rather than an actual living thing. When I hear Lucian curse Thresh for killing his wife, I'm just going to see two puppets acting out some play on a stage, instead of understanding the pain that Lucian went through, and the joy Thresh feels for his acts. When the Three Queens side quest appears, I'm not going to care who wins, because I know what my team does in that match literally does not matter in terms of the overarching story of the game.

What I would have preferred is that champions not ALWAYS be a part of the League. I don't believe the way the League works right now requires a constant commitment to it, and even if it does Riot could retcon that so it works that way. This way, champions don't have to have a specific reason to join the League in their lore (like the new champs) unless it's relevant, and can join when they have a specific reason too. For example, let's say that Demacia is facing off against the Shadow Isles, because reasons. Lucian normally wouldn't be allied with Demacia despite being raised there, but in this case would side with them and join the League. Also, if the lore was handled in this way, there could be events that happen every once in a while, and depending on summoners actions (perhaps Factions battles, perhaps something else), events could end differently. Maybe events could involve special matches, like the 1v1 Snowdowns, or could effect how a champion plays for a while in normal matches. There's a lot of ways that this could have been handled, and I just don't agree that removing the lore from the game is the way to go.

I'll end this with one more thing: someone had made the comparison between this and Super Smash Bros., in that the games we play now are just fantasy matches with League champs. The main fundamental flaw with this thinking is that in SSB, the characters you play are actually dolls or trophies because that's how that game works, and that's really what that game is: pit Nintendo characters against each other because it would be cool to see how they would fight and who would win. League of Legends is not that kind of a game. The characters are not dolls, they are living creatures in the lore. And they deserve to be treated that way, in the game and out.

Which is why that's not how Summoners are in Factions. I should really just do a post about this at this point, but here's the quick version:

* Summoners are powerful mages. They're not all-powerful. The League's power is maintained because Demacia and Noxus see fit to keep it in place (for now), and because the nations of Valoran recognize that without the League as referee sooner or later the planet will blow up.
* Summoners do not mind-control Champions. They back them up, advising them and helping them with magic.
* I don't see Summoners as actually yanking Champions onto the Fields from wherever they may be. Champions show up when they want to show up, but Summoners do have the authority to request their presence. Champions show up for the same reason they joined the League: they win favor (and probably even get paid directly) by the factions who call them forth.
